name: List all issues assigned to the authenticated user across all visible repositories including owned repositories, member repositories, and organization repositories

params.name: filter
params.description:
Indicates which sorts of issues to return. Can be one of:  
\* `assigned`: Issues assigned to you  
\* `created`: Issues created by you  
\* `mentioned`: Issues mentioning you  
\* `subscribed`: Issues you're subscribed to updates for  
\* `all`: All issues the authenticated user can see, regardless of participation or creation

params.name: state
params.description: Indicates the state of the issues to return. Can be either `open`, `closed`, or `all`.

params.name: labels
params.description: A list of comma separated label names. Example: `bug,ui,@high`

params.name: sort
params.description: What to sort results by. Can be either `created`, `updated`, `comments`.

params.name: direction
params.description: The direction of the sort. Can be either `asc` or `desc`.

params.name: since
params.description: Only issues updated at or after this time are returned. This is a timestamp in ISO 8601 format: `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ`.

params.name: per_page
params.description: Results per page (max 100)

params.name: page
params.description: Page number of the results to fetch.

description:
**Note**: In the past, pull requests and issues were more closely aligned than they are now. As far as the API is concerned, every pull request is an issue, but not every issue is a pull request.

This endpoint may also return pull requests in the response. If an issue _is_ a pull request, the object will include a `pull_request` key.

You can use the `filter` query parameter to fetch issues that are not necessarily assigned to you. See the table below for more information.



**Note:** If a user opened an issue via a GitHub App, the `performed_via_github_app` key contains information on that GitHub App.

name: List all issues across owned and member repositories assigned to the authenticated user

params.name: filter
params.description:
Indicates which sorts of issues to return. Can be one of:  
\* `assigned`: Issues assigned to you  
\* `created`: Issues created by you  
\* `mentioned`: Issues mentioning you  
\* `subscribed`: Issues you're subscribed to updates for  
\* `all`: All issues the authenticated user can see, regardless of participation or creation

params.name: state
params.description: Indicates the state of the issues to return. Can be either `open`, `closed`, or `all`.

params.name: labels
params.description: A list of comma separated label names. Example: `bug,ui,@high`

params.name: sort
params.description: What to sort results by. Can be either `created`, `updated`, `comments`.

params.name: direction
params.description: The direction of the sort. Can be either `asc` or `desc`.

params.name: since
params.description: Only issues updated at or after this time are returned. This is a timestamp in ISO 8601 format: `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ`.

params.name: per_page
params.description: Results per page (max 100)

params.name: page
params.description: Page number of the results to fetch.

description:
**Note**: In the past, pull requests and issues were more closely aligned than they are now. As far as the API is concerned, every pull request is an issue, but not every issue is a pull request.

This endpoint may also return pull requests in the response. If an issue _is_ a pull request, the object will include a `pull_request` key.

You can use the `filter` query parameter to fetch issues that are not necessarily assigned to you. See the table below for more information.



**Note:** If a user opened an issue via a GitHub App, the `performed_via_github_app` key contains information on that GitHub App.

name: List all issues for a given organization assigned to the authenticated user

params.name: filter
params.description:
Indicates which sorts of issues to return. Can be one of:  
\* `assigned`: Issues assigned to you  
\* `created`: Issues created by you  
\* `mentioned`: Issues mentioning you  
\* `subscribed`: Issues you're subscribed to updates for  
\* `all`: All issues the authenticated user can see, regardless of participation or creation

params.name: state
params.description: Indicates the state of the issues to return. Can be either `open`, `closed`, or `all`.

params.name: labels
params.description: A list of comma separated label names. Example: `bug,ui,@high`

params.name: sort
params.description: What to sort results by. Can be either `created`, `updated`, `comments`.

params.name: direction
params.description: The direction of the sort. Can be either `asc` or `desc`.

params.name: since
params.description: Only issues updated at or after this time are returned. This is a timestamp in ISO 8601 format: `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ`.

params.name: per_page
params.description: Results per page (max 100)

params.name: page
params.description: Page number of the results to fetch.

description:
**Note**: In the past, pull requests and issues were more closely aligned than they are now. As far as the API is concerned, every pull request is an issue, but not every issue is a pull request.

This endpoint may also return pull requests in the response. If an issue _is_ a pull request, the object will include a `pull_request` key.

You can use the `filter` query parameter to fetch issues that are not necessarily assigned to you. See the table below for more information.



**Note:** If a user opened an issue via a GitHub App, the `performed_via_github_app` key contains information on that GitHub App.

name: List issues for a repository

params.name: milestone
params.description: If an `integer` is passed, it should refer to a milestone by its `number` field. If the string `*` is passed, issues with any milestone are accepted. If the string `none` is passed, issues without milestones are returned.

params.name: state
params.description: Indicates the state of the issues to return. Can be either `open`, `closed`, or `all`.

params.name: assignee
params.description: Can be the name of a user. Pass in `none` for issues with no assigned user, and `*` for issues assigned to any user.

params.name: creator
params.description: The user that created the issue.

params.name: mentioned
params.description: A user that's mentioned in the issue.

params.name: labels
params.description: A list of comma separated label names. Example: `bug,ui,@high`

params.name: sort
params.description: What to sort results by. Can be either `created`, `updated`, `comments`.

params.name: direction
params.description: The direction of the sort. Can be either `asc` or `desc`.

params.name: since
params.description: Only issues updated at or after this time are returned. This is a timestamp in ISO 8601 format: `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ`.

params.name: per_page
params.description: Results per page (max 100)

params.name: page
params.description: Page number of the results to fetch.

description:
**Note**: In the past, pull requests and issues were more closely aligned than they are now. As far as the API is concerned, every pull request is an issue, but not every issue is a pull request.

This endpoint may also return pull requests in the response. If an issue _is_ a pull request, the object will include a `pull_request` key.



**Note:** If a user opened an issue via a GitHub App, the `performed_via_github_app` key contains information on that GitHub App.

name: Get a single issue
description:
**Note**: In the past, pull requests and issues were more closely aligned than they are now. As far as the API is concerned, every pull request is an issue, but not every issue is a pull request.

This endpoint may also return pull requests in the response. If an issue _is_ a pull request, the object will include a `pull_request` key.

name: Create an issue

params.name: title
params.description: The title of the issue.

params.name: body
params.description: The contents of the issue.

params.name: assignee
params.description: Login for the user that this issue should be assigned to. _NOTE: Only users with push access can set the assignee for new issues. The assignee is silently dropped otherwise. **This field is deprecated.**_

params.name: milestone
params.description: The `number` of the milestone to associate this issue with. _NOTE: Only users with push access can set the milestone for new issues. The milestone is silently dropped otherwise._

params.name: labels
params.description: Labels to associate with this issue. _NOTE: Only users with push access can set labels for new issues. Labels are silently dropped otherwise._

params.name: assignees
params.description: Logins for Users to assign to this issue. _NOTE: Only users with push access can set assignees for new issues. Assignees are silently dropped otherwise._

description: Any user with pull access to a repository can create an issue.

name: Edit an issue

params.name: title
params.description: The title of the issue.

params.name: body
params.description: The contents of the issue.

params.name: assignee
params.description: Login for the user that this issue should be assigned to. **This field is deprecated.**

params.name: state
params.description: State of the issue. Either `open` or `closed`.

params.name: milestone
params.description: The `number` of the milestone to associate this issue with or `null` to remove current. _NOTE: Only users with push access can set the milestone for issues. The milestone is silently dropped otherwise._

params.name: labels
params.description: Labels to associate with this issue. Pass one or more Labels to _replace_ the set of Labels on this Issue. Send an empty array (`[]`) to clear all Labels from the Issue. _NOTE: Only users with push access can set labels for issues. Labels are silently dropped otherwise._

params.name: assignees
params.description: Logins for Users to assign to this issue. Pass one or more user logins to _replace_ the set of assignees on this Issue. Send an empty array (`[]`) to clear all assignees from the Issue. _NOTE: Only users with push access can set assignees for new issues. Assignees are silently dropped otherwise._

description: Issue owners and users with push access can edit an issue.

name: Lock an issue

params.name: lock_reason
params.description:
The reason for locking the issue or pull request conversation. Lock will fail if you don't use one of these reasons:  
\* `off-topic`  
\* `too heated`  
\* `resolved`  
\* `spam`

description:
Users with push access can lock an issue or pull request's conversation.

Note that, if you choose not to pass any parameters, you'll need to set `Content-Length` to zero when calling out to this endpoint. For more information, see "[HTTP verbs](/v3/#http-verbs)."

name: Unlock an issue
description: Users with push access can unlock an issue's conversation.

name: List assignees

params.name: per_page
params.description: Results per page (max 100)

params.name: page
params.description: Page number of the results to fetch.

description: Lists the [available assignees](https://help.github.com/articles/assigning-issues-and-pull-requests-to-other-github-users/) for issues in a repository.

name: Check assignee
description:
Checks if a user has permission to be assigned to an issue in this repository.

If the `assignee` can be assigned to issues in the repository, a `204` header with no content is returned.

Otherwise a `404` status code is returned.

name: Add assignees to an issue

params.name: assignees
params.description: Usernames of people to assign this issue to. _NOTE: Only users with push access can add assignees to an issue. Assignees are silently ignored otherwise._

description:
Adds up to 10 assignees to an issue. Users already assigned to an issue are not replaced.

This example adds two assignees to the existing `octocat` assignee.

name: Remove assignees from an issue

params.name: assignees
params.description: Usernames of assignees to remove from an issue. _NOTE: Only users with push access can remove assignees from an issue. Assignees are silently ignored otherwise._

description:
Removes one or more assignees from an issue.

This example removes two of three assignees, leaving the `octocat` assignee.

name: List comments on an issue

params.name: since
params.description: Only comments updated at or after this time are returned. This is a timestamp in ISO 8601 format: `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ`.

params.name: per_page
params.description: Results per page (max 100)

params.name: page
params.description: Page number of the results to fetch.

description: Issue Comments are ordered by ascending ID.

name: List comments in a repository

params.name: sort
params.description: Either `created` or `updated`.

params.name: direction
params.description: Either `asc` or `desc`. Ignored without the `sort` parameter.

params.name: since
params.description: Only comments updated at or after this time are returned. This is a timestamp in ISO 8601 format: `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ`.

description: By default, Issue Comments are ordered by ascending ID.

name: Get a single comment

params.name: per_page
params.description: Results per page (max 100)

params.name: page
params.description: Page number of the results to fetch.

description: **Note:** If a user created an issue comment via a GitHub App, the `performed_via_github_app` key will contain information on that GitHub App.

params.name: body
params.description: The contents of the comment.

params.name: body
params.description: The contents of the comment.

params.name: per_page
params.description: Results per page (max 100)

params.name: page
params.description: Page number of the results to fetch.

params.name: per_page
params.description: Results per page (max 100)

params.name: page
params.description: Page number of the results to fetch.

name: Get a single event
description: **Note:** If the event was triggered by a user via a GitHub App, the `performed_via_github_app` key will contain information on that GitHub App.

name: List all labels for this repository

params.name: per_page
params.description: Results per page (max 100)

params.name: page
params.description: Page number of the results to fetch.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of the label. Emoji can be added to label names, using either native emoji or colon-style markup. For example, typing `:strawberry:` will render the emoji ![:strawberry:](https://a248.e.akamai.net/assets.github.com/images/icons/emoji/unicode/1f353.png ":strawberry:"). For a full list of available emoji and codes, see [emoji-cheat-sheet.com](http://emoji-cheat-sheet.com/).

params.name: color
params.description: The [hexadecimal color code](http://www.color-hex.com/) for the label, without the leading `#`.

params.name: description
params.description: A short description of the label.

params.name: name
params.description: The name of the label. Emoji can be added to label names, using either native emoji or colon-style markup. For example, typing `:strawberry:` will render the emoji ![:strawberry:](https://a248.e.akamai.net/assets.github.com/images/icons/emoji/unicode/1f353.png ":strawberry:"). For a full list of available emoji and codes, see [emoji-cheat-sheet.com](http://emoji-cheat-sheet.com/).

params.name: color
params.description: The [hexadecimal color code](http://www.color-hex.com/) for the label, without the leading `#`.

params.name: description
params.description: A short description of the label.

params.name: per_page
params.description: Results per page (max 100)

params.name: page
params.description: Page number of the results to fetch.

Replace all labels for an issue
description: Sending an empty array (`[]`) will remove all Labels from the Issue.
